data.title: Operation Nemesis : Throughline
data.meta_description: An estimated 1.5 million Armenian Christians were killed by the Ottoman government during World War I, in what came to be known as the Armenian Genocide. The perpetrators escaped Constantinople in the middle of the night and began new lives undercover in Europe. So, a small group of Armenian survivors decided to take justice into their own hands. In this episode from Kerning Cultures, the secretive operation to avenge the Armenian Genocide, and how it changed the idea of justice in the modern world. This story originally aired on Kerning Cultures, a podcast telling stories from across the Middle East and North Africa and the spaces in between.
data.text:
RUND ABDELFATAH, HOST:

Hey, Rund here.

RAMTIN ARABLOUEI, HOST:

And Ramtin.

ABDELFATAH: A note about what you're about to hear - this episode contains graphic descriptions of violence. If kids are listening or you'd rather not hear that, I'd suggest skipping this one.

ARABLOUEI: Here's reporters Alex Atack and Hebah Fisher.

ALEX ATACK: Our story begins on the last day of Talaat Pasha's life on an ordinary road in the center of Berlin. He'd been living in an apartment here, No. 4 Hardenbergstrasse, for some years now, and he'd grown comfortable in his routine. Every day, about 11 o'clock, he'd walk the few blocks into town to a tobacco shop, and that's what he was doing on the morning that we're talking about, March 15, 1921. But what he didn't know that morning is that he was being watched.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

ATACK: As Talaat stepped out of his front door, he was wearing a striped shirt and leaning on a walking stick. In the old days, he was known for his kind of trademark thick mustache, kind of like a walrus, but he shaved it off a few years back as a precaution in case anyone recognized him. As he walked through the doorway that listed his apartment number next to a fake name, a young Armenian man called Soghomon Tehlirian was waiting for him, looking down at the street from the window of an apartment on the other side of the road.

MICHAEL GAVLAK: Soghomon knows, this is it. This is the moment.

ATACK: This is Michael Gavlak. He's a movie producer working on a film about Soghomon Tehlirian.

GAVLAK: And he grabs his gun, grabs his coat, heads out. I mean, he knew this was his duty, and so he had to get it right. This has to happen correctly. I can't get the wrong guy. I'm not going to kill an innocent man. I don't want any bystanders harmed. This guy deserves to die, and I'm the one appointed to do it. Nobody else will.

So he stays parallel on the other side of the street and accelerates on the other side of the street to get ahead of him. And then he crosses the street up in front of Talaat so he can walk towards him 'cause Soghomon wants to get a positive ID. And in a split second, Soghomon put the gun right under Talaat's left ear and pulled the trigger.

And the way that autopsy describes how Talaat died, it says his brain exploded, and he fell, dropped like a rock straight down, and his skull cracked on the sidewalk, and the blood immediately started oozing.

ATACK: The blood was oozing from the head of the man who was the grand vizier of the Ottoman government during the Armenian genocide. Usually, he's known as Talaat Pasha, but Pasha is an honorific, and it doesn't feel right to use it here.

HEBAH FISHER: Between 1915 and 1917, he oversaw the Ottoman military during one of the darkest chapters in recent history. Under his supervision, his soldiers murdered over 1 1/2 million Armenians and other Christian minorities from the Ottoman Empire.

ATACK: And Soghomon Tehlirian - that was the assassin standing over Talaat looking down as his blood pooled on the sidewalk - he was part of a secretive assassination plot to avenge the Armenian lives lost in those years. Why - I suppose, like, why assassination as opposed to, I don't know, anything else?

MARIAN MESROBIAN MACCURDY: What else is there? They were tried, convicted of capital crimes. What else is there?

ATACK: This is the Armenian American writer Marian Mesrobian MacCurdy.

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: Do you torture them? Do you, you know - I don't know? They wanted Talaat to die.

ABDELFATAH: When we come back, we'll introduce you to a podcast we really like, "Kerning Cultures," and their episode about Operation Nemesis, the story of a secretive group of ordinary Armenians seeking justice when governments fail to, who plotted to take out the top Ottoman officials in charge of the Armenian genocide...

ARABLOUEI: ...And how their operation changed the way the world thinks of justice. You're listening to THROUGHLINE from NPR.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

ABDELFATAH: This week, we want to bring you something we heard that really stuck with us. It's from a podcast called "Kerning Cultures."

ARABLOUEI: "Kerning Cultures" tells stories from across the Middle East and North Africa and the spaces in between. We wanted to share one of their episodes in particular.

ABDELFATAH: As you heard, it's a story about the Armenian genocide and what happened afterwards. During World War I, some estimates are that 1 1/2 million Armenians were exterminated by what was then the Ottoman Empire and is now Turkey.

ARABLOUEI: For over a century, even as genocide has become a widely used term, Turkey has refused to acknowledge what happened to the Armenian people, which means that any country that addresses it has had to risk angering Turkish authorities.

ABDELFATAH: The U.S. has wrestled with how to handle such a sensitive issue. Turkey is a longtime ally. Ronald Reagan was the first U.S. president to call it a genocide. Both candidates George W. Bush and Barack Obama said they would and then both backed down when they became president. In 2019, the U.S. House and Senate passed resolutions formally recognizing it as such. Then...

(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER #1: We want to bring you some breaking news coming into us from the United States. President Joe Biden has formally recognized the massacre of Armenians under the Ottoman Empire during World War I as an act of genocide.

(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER #2: And breaking news out of Washington, D.C., President Biden today became the first U.S. president to formally acknowledge the killing of more than a million Armenians by Ottoman Turks more than a century ago as being a genocide.

(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER #3: This is a step that a bunch of American presidents have not taken - No. 1, because Turkey is such a strategic ally - also because Turkey has always denied that genocide as defined by international law ever occurred. So, Fred, as you asked...

ABDELFATAH: But today's episode is not about the struggle to get the Armenian genocide officially acknowledged. It's about a small number of Armenian survivors in the years right after the genocide who refused to wait for the world to pay attention and instead decided that justice meant taking matters into their own hands.

ARABLOUEI: After the break, producer Alex Atack from the "Kerning Cultures" podcast brings us the story of Operation Nemesis.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

ATACK: So the first person I spoke to for this story was Marian - actually, could you just introduce yourself? Just tell me your name and, like, however you want to be introduced.

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: My name is Marian Mesrobian MacCurdy. I was born in Syracuse, N.Y. and now live in Massachusetts. And I came upon this story in a very strange, circuitous way, which I guess is what we will talk about.

ATACK: And we started our interview talking about her childhood, growing up with her Armenian grandparents - their names were Aaron and Eliza Sachaklian - in Syracuse, N.Y.

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: My grandfather used to bounce me on his leg, you know, singing these kid stories - kid songs, you know? What was the one that he used to do? This little horsey (ph) goes walk, walk, walk. This little horsey goes trot, trot, trot. This little horsey goes gallop, gallop, gallop.

And he would throw me up in the air, you know? I would sit on his shoulders, and he'd walk around the house, and, you know, I touched the doorframes. To me, they were like, you know, the top of Ararat. It was so - they were so tall. I loved him, and he loved me.

ATACK: Marian and her grandparents were close. She lived under their roof until she was around 6 or 7. Her grandmother, Eliza, was a singer and a homemaker and a well-known figure in the Armenian community in Syracuse. Her grandfather, Aaron, was an accountant.

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: He was a gentleman and a good person, just a very good person - super smart, but in a low-key way. He didn't have to demonstrate anything to anybody.

ATACK: Marian grew up with her Armenian identity as a constant backdrop to her life in America. Her grandmother didn't speak that much English and mostly spoke to the family in Armenian, but she had a great relationship with her grandchildren. Marian remembers weekends where she'd take her to the movies and buy her caramel corn and chocolate from the vendor. And kind of throughout her childhood, her grandparents would pass down stories and folklores, probably similar versions of stories that pass through many Armenian American households at the time. And one of those stories was the story of Operation Nemesis.

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: I was born knowing about Operation Nemesis. I don't think you can be an Armenian and not know about Operation Nemesis (laughter).

ATACK: The men who were behind Talaat's assassination, as well as the assassination of seven other Ottoman government officials in the two years after it, had become folk heroes in a way, but their stories were distant. They were almost like urban legends by this point, by the time Marian was growing up, because the organizers of Operation Nemesis had wanted to keep the whole thing a secret. Pieces of information had leaked out here and there, and a book was written in the 1980s, but any official records were either lost or sealed.

Marian's grandfather died in 1964, and her grandmother died in 1990. And after that, Marian and her mum began clearing out the family home and organizing her grandparents' things.

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: My mother and I were going through her house, and my mother found these files in a file cabinet that was right next to my childhood bedroom.

ATACK: And at first, it just looked like it was, like, full of regular stuff that you might find in an accountant's cupboard.

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: Things like letters and telegrams, invoices, bills.

ATACK: Most of them were written in Armenian, and Marian's mum gathered up the documents and started cataloging them.

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: And she came to me, and she said, Marian, I have something I have to talk to you about. So we sat down, and we looked at them. And I was just flabbergasted.

ATACK: Marian's grandfather wasn't just an accountant, as she'd always thought. He was one of the organizers of Operation Nemesis, one of the Armenian folk heroes that she'd grown up hearing about. And these documents were basically a treasure trove of records that were kind of a timeline of everything that happened throughout Operation Nemesis. But they'd been a secret for decades. Even her grandfather had never told anyone about his involvement in the operation, not even his wife, Eliza.

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: Not a word.

ATACK: Wow.

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: That guy could keep a secret.

ATACK: And when you found them, they were just in a filing cabinet that - what, it had always been locked? You'd never looked inside it before? You'd never noticed it before?

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: I don't even know if it had a lock.

ATACK: Oh.

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: He was an accountant. He had files. Accountants had files.

(LAUGHTER)

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: So that's what we found. And the more we read, the more fascinated I got by this story.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

ATACK: And to take the story back, I guess, all the way to the beginning, Marian's grandfather, Aaron, was born in the Ottoman Empire, modern-day Turkey, in a city called Malatya on September 9, 1879. But he left his family home when he was a teenager. His brother had emigrated to the U.S. a couple of years earlier, and Aaron wanted to join him. He had to bribe police officers to let him on the ship in Constantinople because Armenians weren't allowed to leave Turkey at the time.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: Armenians had lived in a second-class status world. There were these enclaves of Armenians within the Turkish population, but they were governed very differently.

ATACK: After a trip that lasted a good few months and went via Marseilles in France, he finally arrived in America and straight away moved to a place called Hartford, Conn.

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: My grandfather, when he first came to the United States, went to school. He learned English. And he went to Huntzingser's (ph) - Huntsingser (ph) - Huntinger's (ph) - oh, God, I can't say that word. He went to Huntsinger's Business Academy, and he got a degree and ultimately became an accountant.

ATACK: But he would still make occasional trips back to his home country. And on one of these trips, he met Eliza, Marian's grandmother. He was 30, and she was 18. They got talking in the corner of a party one evening, and a couple of months later, they were engaged. This was 1910, so a year after the end of Adana massacres, the second wave of killings inflicted on Armenians by the Ottoman government, but before the Armenian genocide.

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: And those massacres were serious because the towns that were involved were wiped out completely. It wasn't like, you know, you could escape or run away. They were done. So luckily, he got her out before the genocide.

ATACK: Gosh.

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: Or, you know, that would have been that.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

ATACK: Right after they got married, Aaron brought Eliza back to the U.S. with him. And although she felt homesick in America and she didn't speak the language too well, moving there with Aaron was kind of an escape from the persecution that Armenians were facing back home. In the meantime, Aaron regularly worked abroad. He worked as an accountant for the U.S. government, and he regularly made trips back to his hometown in Ottoman Turkey. It's not exactly clear when, but on one of these visits in the years before the genocide, he got involved with a group called the Armenian Revolutionary Federation, the ARF. They were basically a political party formed with the idea to defend Armenians from increasing oppression by the Ottoman government.

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: I think my grandfather knew that the Armenians would never be safe in Turkey - never - unless they somehow or another pushed back against the Turks. They weren't looking to revolt. They weren't looking to start a new country at the time. They were looking to get granted to them the kinds of rights that other Turkish citizens had.

ATACK: But that didn't ever happen. This rising political party called the CUP, or the Young Turks, as you might know them, were increasingly pushing this idea of Turkification, an Ottoman Empire for ethnic Turks and nobody else.

ERIC BOGOSIAN: It's so parallel to what happened in Nazi Germany, it's kind of uncanny.

ATACK: This is Eric Bogosian. He's an Armenian American writer and actor. In 2015, he wrote a book called "Operation Nemesis," which is one of the most thorough recent accounts of this story that we have.

BOGOSIAN: There was a whole sort of movement to solve the Armenian problem. What's the Armenian problem? The Armenian problem is that you've got Christians with a lot of power living and thriving in the Ottoman Empire. So there was this faction, a very big faction, of the CUP that said, this is how we solve it.

ATACK: In 1915, the Armenian genocide began to unfold in stages. I won't go into too much detail, but as a trigger warning, I'm about to relay some of what happened during those years as documented by many historians and genocide experts.

On April 24, 1915, Talaat ordered the rounding up of more than 200 Armenian leaders and intellectuals and journalists and academics and had them all deported. Ottoman soldiers closed in on Armenian villages and burned them to the ground. These tapes are from a series of oral history interviews with Armenian genocide survivors.

(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

UNIDENTIFIED PERSON #1: They came in our city, and they took everything away from us overnight. They told us next day, we have to get up and walk and leave everything behind.

ATACK: In larger villages, they targeted men first. They were rounded up and imprisoned and, in many cases, tortured. The remaining Armenians - women, children and the elderly and people with disabilities - were told that they were to be temporarily moved out of their homes and towns. They were told to make a list of everything they owned, including their livestock, and hand that list to an Ottoman official. They said that they'd make sure everything was there waiting for them when they got back, but it wasn't. And most of them never came back.

(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

UNIDENTIFIED PERSON #2: They started killing. People running from - trying to hide someplace. But they were killing.

ATACK: They were marched out in caravans guarded by Ottoman soldiers or packed into train carriages. People who tried to resist were killed with guns and bayonets. Many people died by suicide. Others died of thirst and hunger or disease, and their bodies were often left at the side of the road.

(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

UNIDENTIFIED PERSON #3: My baby sister died on the train there. She was only 4 years old. And my parents just buried her by the railroad tracks there. From then on...

ATACK: Those who survived were abandoned at outposts in the Syrian desert near what is now Deir ez-Zor. The people who survived the horrors that their families had not were left to die there.

(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

UNIDENTIFIED PERSON #3: As much as I could see, this column of human beings walked behind the same thing, and nobody said anything. They knew they were going to die soon.

ATACK: There was no point in history where so many people had died in such a short period of time. The atrocities that were committed against the Armenians in those years are too awful and, frankly, just too evil for me to ever capture in a few sentences.

BOGOSIAN: In all, we don't really know how many people were killed, but the number seems to me between a million and 2 million. One thing we know for sure - Armenians were a real presence in Ottoman Turkey. And that region - those regions have almost no Armenians in them today, at least people who identify as Armenians.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

ATACK: Relatively little information reached the outside world at the time. But there were survivors and diplomats and foreign ambassadors who wrote accounts of what they'd seen in the Ottoman Empire and their inability to do anything about it. Foreign governments were aware of what was happening, too.

TESSA HOFMANN: It was more than aware.

ATACK: This is the historian Tessa Hofmann. She's a scholar of Armenian studies at Berlin Free University.

HOFMANN: The German ambassador, very early - in early July 1915, wrote to his government that the persecution of the Armenians now is nationwide, not only in areas near to the front line. In reality, it is an extermination of the Armenian population.

ATACK: Overseeing all of this misery was a small group of political leaders from the CUP known as the Three Pashas - Talaat Pasha, Enver Pasha and Djemal Pasha.

BOGOSIAN: Talaat ran the country with Enver and Djemal. But I think everybody believed and understood that Talaat was really the guy who organized everything and was really keeping an eye on the big picture.

ATACK: After the genocide had ended, there was a shift in the empire's politics. The Ottoman Empire was on the losing side of World War I. And this is a bit of a simplification, but the new Turkish government, which was run by Kemal Ataturk, they had to hold a series of tribunals or court cases to determine who was responsible for the Armenian genocide. It was part of the treaty they signed at the end of the war.

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: The Turkish tribunals had more serious repercussions for those that were convicted of capital crimes. And those were the three primary culprits here, among them, of course, Talaat Pasha.

ATACK: And in these tribunals, the Three Pashas - Talaat, Enver and Djemal - along with other CUP leaders, were charged with the massacres of Armenians and Greeks and sentenced to death.

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: So it looked like maybe there was going to be some kind of justice, but then they were allowed to escape.

ATACK: Before the tribunals had even started, Talaat, Enver, Djemal and some other CUP members boarded a torpedo boat called the Loreley with the help of German diplomats and escaped out of Constantinople.

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: On November 1, 2 - it was around midnight, so which - you know, was it November 1 or 2 of 1918? - they escaped. And they got onto a German boat. And they went across the Black Sea, and they escaped to Germany and then other points after that.

ATACK: Some of them made their way to Moscow, others to Rome, where they all slipped into undercover identities and became basically untouchable and unfindable by British or French forces.

HOFMANN: So his court proceedings came to no end. And the death sentences that were declared were usually declared in absentia.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

ATACK: So the U.S. contingent of the Armenian Revolutionary Federation - that's the political organization Marian's grandfather was involved with - they were starting to see how the story of their murdered families was being used and told halfway across the world, and they decided they wanted to act.

BOGOSIAN: And this is where the Armenians come in, and they start knocking these guys off.

ATACK: The ARF held their general congress meeting in Yerevan in September 1919, and two Armenians traveled over from the U.S. to present their assassination idea to the group. There was an intense discussion. Many of the ARF members didn't agree that assassination was the answer. But the general congress voted, and they approved what they called a special mission - Operation Nemesis.

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: My grandfather and Shahan Natalie and Armen Garo were the three leaders of Nemesis.

ATACK: The way Marian puts it, Shahan was the heart of the operation, Armen was the head and her grandfather, Aaron, was the mind.

BOGOSIAN: Armen Garo was a celebrated activist. He is a political animal.

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: His family had been wiped out in the genocide. Shahan Natalie's father had been murdered by the Turks. So they all had reasons, you know? They all had personal reasons.

BOGOSIAN: And in many ways, it's kind of like you f*** with my people, I'm going to get your people.

ATACK: Their idea was to clean the debt, as they put it - to find and assassinate the Ottoman leaders who were responsible for the genocide and now hiding out all over Europe.

BOGOSIAN: These are not highly (laughter) trained agents. These are a bunch of small businessmen in New England who make a decision that this will not stand, and they must answer it.

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: So that's the feeling that the Armenians carried with them, that there's nobody but us. We have to do this ourselves. So that's what they did.

ATACK: The first thing they needed to do was to recruit a team of people to carry out the operation.

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: They put an ad in somewhere. I don't remember where. And it's a actually very funny ad because it talks about applicants should be bachelors (laughter) or something like that, you know? You know, so they did not think these people were coming back (laughter), right? I think that they thought that this is a, you know, not a mission that you would return from, so you better just, you know, settle your affairs and come. And people volunteer. They did.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

ATACK: And then they started to put together a list of names, the people that they would target.

BOGOSIAN: And a list is made of 100 nefarious individuals from the Ottoman government who had been making this genocide happen during World War I. And they were going to go down the list.

ATACK: So you actually have a handwritten copy of the list of 100 names, right?

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: I do (laughter). That was stunning to find. It's in Shahan Natalie's handwriting, and it's on ordinary paper. Of course, it's yellowed over the years.

ATACK: This is from one of the documents that Marian found when she was cleaning out her grandparents' house.

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: So No. 1 on the list, as you can expect, was...

UNIDENTIFIED PERSON #4: (Distorted) Talaat Pasha.

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: So that was No. 1.

UNIDENTIFIED PERSON #4: (Distorted) Said Halim Pasha.

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: ...Was the former grand vizier, former minister of foreign affairs, ex-president of Central Committee of the Ittihad. And the third was...

UNIDENTIFIED PERSON #4: (Distorted) Enver, minister of war.

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: ...Commander of the Ottoman Army. He was a fugitive. And the fourth was...

UNIDENTIFIED PERSON #4: (Distorted) General Pasha, minister of the marine.

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: He was also a fugitive. And then the list goes on after that. They wanted to make sure that they got those grand viziers, and so they worked off this list.

BOGOSIAN: So they make this list, and they need the guy who's going to do the deed.

ATACK: And this is where Soghomon Tehlirian comes back into our story. He was a young guy. He was around 22 at the end of the genocide, and he'd survived it because he was fighting with the Soviet army against the Ottoman Empire on the Soviet front. But after the war ended, he made a trip back to his hometown called Erzincan and found that it was decimated. In the Armenian district, everything was just gone. Buildings had been burned down or demolished, and his childhood home had been turned into Russian army barracks. His family were gone, and he had no way of finding out what had happened to them.

BOGOSIAN: You're talking about a young soldier who enters his own hometown to find that everybody, 25,000 fellow Armenians, have disappeared. And he eventually finds out they were murdered, including his own family. And I think this is an intensely traumatic experience for him, one that he, in order to keep living, he has to answer. Otherwise, he's going to lose his mind.

ATACK: So he made his way to Constantinople, which had become kind of a safe haven for Armenian refugees at the end of World War I. By all accounts, including his own memoir, he was an introspective and quiet man, skinny with pushed-back dark hair and high cheekbones. For months after the genocide, he walked the streets of Constantinople amongst the crowds of British and French soldiers and refugees from the war, trying to find out what had happened to his family.

And then one evening, a friend told him about an Armenian man who had collaborated with the Turks at the start of the genocide. He said that he was still alive and living free in Constantinople. Tehlirian obsessed over him, and one night waited outside the man's house, watching as he ate dinner with a table of guests. Tehlirian raised a gun to the window and shot him. He found out later that the man had been rushed to hospital and died the next day. At 23 years old, Tehlirian had just made his first kill. His second, he decided, was going to be Talaat.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

ATACK: We'll be right back.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

ATACK: When we left off, Soghomon Tehlirian was in Istanbul, having just killed an Armenian who had helped the Turkish authorities during the genocide.

BOGOSIAN: So now we have this guy who has it in his head that his ultimate goal in life is to kill Talaat Pasha. And somehow, the guys in Massachusetts find out about this fella, Soghomon Tehlirian.

ATACK: Shahan Natalie from Operation Nemesis, who was in Boston at the time - he got word of Tehlirian and what he'd done and decided that he wanted to meet him. They had him visit Operation Nemesis HQ in Boston. Tehlirian traveled over to America in August 1920 on the Olympic, which was Titanic's sister ship. The Operation Nemesis team spent a few days vetting him...

BOGOSIAN: So he gets looked over, and he is a perfect guy for the job because he can handle a gun, and he has a great vibe. I mean, he looks very innocent. He looks very sweet. He's young. He's in his early 20s.

ATACK: ...And decided ultimately that Tehlirian was going to be the guy they were going to trust with the assassination of Talaat, the most important person on their list.

Meanwhile, Talaat was still living in Berlin. He'd actually said that he half-expected to be assassinated by Armenians seeking revenge to the point where the German secret service had recommended that he move to a manor house on the outskirts of Berlin. But he didn't want to. He stayed at his apartment, No. 4 Hardenbergstrasse, hiding in plain sight.

BOGOSIAN: Now, Talaat was known for a distinguishing feature, which was a big sort of walrus mustache, and he had shaved it off. And he was moving around pretty freely in Berlin, being protected by the Turkish Consulate there. And he was going under an assumed name and was pretty much invisible. So how do the Armenian agents find these guys? Well, they - the first thing they do is - they can all pass for Turkish, and they can all speak Turkish fluently.

ATACK: So they spend a lot of time hanging around in coffee shops where Turks were known to gather, and they'd basically just listen in. They also spread word around Armenian communities that they were on the lookout for Turk leaders, and they bribed border guards all across Europe.

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: And that helped because the border guards would then tell them, you know, this guy had a Turkish passport, and this is what he looked like. And it actually was useful in tracking Talaat from Switzerland into Germany. These guys didn't have internet, you know? They didn't even have the phone. They didn't have anything except letters. How do you conduct such a deeply difficult enterprise - how do you do that? - without all the aids that we have now? How do you do that just with the mail?

ATACK: For their letters, they made up a kind of secret code so that they could communicate between the U.S. and Europe without anybody else intercepting and understanding them.

MESROBIAN MACCURDY: (Laughter) Well, I found one code system. I don't know how many others they had, but this is a very strange one. So there was this document that had gibberish on it. You know, I thought, oh, that's really strange. And I kept poking around, and then I saw a folded piece of paper that had cutouts on it. And I put the folded piece of paper with the cutouts on top of the document that was gibberish, and suddenly, it's not gibberish.

BOGOSIAN: And slowly but surely, the noose tightens.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

GAVLAK: They narrowed it down to a couple of countries, and then they finally narrowed it down to Berlin.

ATACK: Again, that's film producer Michael Gavlak. After months of searching, one of their sources pulled through, and they got word that Talaat was hiding out in Berlin.

GAVLAK: And so they send Soghomon in. They put him up in an apartment, and they start doing surveillance

ATACK: Through one of their sources, they'd heard that a group of exiled Turkish leaders were meeting in Italy, and that someday soon, Talaat was going to be boarding a train from Berlin to Rome. So they began staking out the train station in Berlin. And one day, they saw somebody who looked like he could be Talaat. He had the right build, with the huge broad shoulders and the walking stick, but didn't have the big walrus mustache that he was known for. And he didn't get on the train like they'd been told he would.
